Other Information.Additional Info: CO2 adsorption benefits from the additional pore space generated by gate opening.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion due to lack of second adsorption step

Other Information.Additional Info: N2 does not benefit from the additional pore space created by framework flexing.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Quantum sieving enabled by framework flexing

Other Information.Threshold Pressure: Varies with temperature (e.g., 0.07 mbar for H2 at boiling point)
Other Information.Additional Info: H2 selectivity decreases as temperature increases due to closed additional pores at higher temperatures.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Kinetic quantum sieving in newly created void space

Other Information.Threshold Pressure: Varies with temperature (e.g., 0.04 mbar for D2 at boiling point)
Other Information.Additional Info: D2 diffuses faster than H2 in the newly created void space, enhancing selectivity.
C2H2 induces structural transformation and increased uptake.
C2H4 induces structural transformation and increased uptake.
C2H6 induces structural transformation and increased uptake.

Sieving Mechanism: Flexing of the framework creates additional pore space, enabling selective adsorption.

Experimental Validation.Method: Breakthrough experiments, thermal desorption spectroscopy (TDS), and GCMC simulation
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: CO2/N2 selectivity improves under flexible conditions; highest H2/D2 selectivity is 14.3 at 40 K and 250 mbar.

Other Information.Additional Info: The flexibility of MUF-15-OMe enhances gas separation by creating additional pore space upon gate opening.
